stories.title: Corporate Carbon Offset Company Accidentally Starts Devastating Wildfire

stories.text:
I can't help but notice the similarity between an OS instance and an organism. It has a boundary and defenses (firewall), various ways of interacting with its environment (network), it has resources and "organs" of its own (processes, RAM, nonvolatile storage) etc. The instances don't (yet) themselves reproduce, but are cloned ad infinitum.

The metaphor goes further when recognizing that computer "viruses" infect these "organisms", commandeering their capabilities for propagation.

What if we treated an OS instance more fully like an organism, and allowed it to evolve and "fight" for its survival? Could it become more secure by virtue of its survival being on the line?

What if OSes could reproduce sexually?

I know this is getting weird but... we use genetic algorithms to evolve solutions to problems.

Is there a place for evolving the operating system itself?
stories.title: Ask HN: Evolutionary Operating Systems?

stories.text:
I have a slight dilemma, I am a CS graduate with no experience in real software development jobs. I can't get a job for two main reasons:

1) There are NO local jobs (I live in a shitty developing country). 2) Can't relocate to a different country due to financial issues. Aka, I don't have that much money.

What I am trying to do is get internships or preferably a remote junior position with only my CS degree.

Is this possible? Could you guide me?
stories.title: Ask HN: Are Remote Internships/Junior Positions Easy to Find?
